title:
An asymptotically consistent morphoelastic shell model for compressible
  biological structures with finite-strain deformations
abstract:
We derive an asymptotically consistent morphoelastic shell model to describe
the finite deformations of biological tissues using the variational
asymptotical method. Biological materials may exhibit remarkable
compressibility when under large deformations, and we take this factor into
account for accurate predictions of their morphoelastic changes. The
morphoelastic shell model combines the growth model of Rodriguez et al. and a
novel shell model developed by us. We start from the three-dimensional (3D)
morphoelastic model and construct the optimal shell energy based on a series
expansion around the middle surface. A two-step variational method is applied
that retains the leading-order expansion coefficient while eliminating the
higher-order ones. The main outcome is a two-dimensional (2D) shell energy
depending on the stretching and bending strains of the middle surface. The
derived morphoelastic shell model is asymptotically consistent with
three-dimensional morphoelasticity and can recover various shell models in
literature. Several examples are shown for the verification and illustration.
